DataElement.preferredDefinition: the measurement of one of the seven base units of the International System of Units (Systeme International d'Unites, SI), the unit of electric current, named after the French physicist Andre Ampere of a chest computed tomography scan.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information relating to one of the seven base units of the International System of Units (Systeme International d'Unites, SI), the unit of electric current, named after the French physicist Andre Ampere of a chest computed tomography scan.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The part of the human body between the neck and the diaphragm or the corresponding part in other vertebrates.:Tomography using x-ray transmission and a computer algorithm to reconstruct the image.

Concepts.definition: The anterior side of the thorax from the neck to the abdomen. The shape of the chest is often regarded as potential insight into a disease process, as in the case of barrel chest and respiratory dysfunction.
A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

Property.preferredDefinition: One of the seven base units of the International System of Units (Systeme International d'Unites, SI), the unit of electric current, named after the French physicist Andre Ampere. It is that constant current which, if maintained in two straight parallel conductors of infinite length and zero diameter separated by one meter in a vacuum, would produce between these conductors a force equal to 2x10(e)7 newton per meter of length. This is dependent upon the definitions of the meter, kilogram, and second. One ampere represents 6.24 x 10(e+18) unit electric charge carriers, such as electrons, passing a specified fixed point in one second.

Concepts.definition: One of the seven base units of the International System of Units (Systeme International d'Unites, SI), the unit of electric current, named after the French physicist Andre Ampere. It is that constant current which, if maintained in two straight parallel conductors of infinite length and zero diameter separated by one meter in a vacuum, would produce between these conductors a force equal to 2x10(e)7 newton per meter of length. This is dependent upon the definitions of the meter, kilogram, and second. One ampere represents 6.24 x 10(e+18) unit electric charge carriers, such as electrons, passing a specified fixed point in one second.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Measurement; the size or magnitude of something.

Concepts.definition: Annotation used to indicate the size or magnitude of something that was determined by comparison to a standard.
